Award.AwardTitle: An Assessment of Education Research Doctorate Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The American Education Research Association (AERA) in conjunction with the National Academy of Education (NAEd) will conduct a multidimensional study of research doctorate programs in education to parallel the large-scale assessment undertaken by the National Research Council (NRC) of 62 other fields. The NRC declined to examine research doctorates in education. Education research is among the largest doctorate-producing fields and the sole one dedicated to understanding science and mathematics education, learning, literacy, and performance. Yet there has been no comprehensive study of research doctorate programs in this field nor has there been an assessment of the state of education and training.

Like the NRC assessment, the AERA-NAEd study assesses the characteristics and quality of education research doctorate programs through (1) quantitative data based on questionnaires from institutions, programs, faculty and students; and (2) faculty publication and citation data and dissertation key words. Mathematica Policy Research, Inc. will undertake the fieldwork, data cleaning and database preparation. This is the same organization that does the NRC survey, so results from this study can be integrated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Assessment of Education Research Doctorate Programs (AERA-NAEd DocStudy) primarily aims to advance knowledge about education research doctorate programs in universities in the United States. The study includes 569 education research doctorate programs across 17 fields in 96 institutions participating in this study. Participating institutions represent nearly three quarters of all those offering at least one education research doctorate program in the benchmark year (academic year 2008-2009), and include 87% of the high research activity universities offering a doctorate in education. The project is a joint initiative of the American Educational Research Association (AERA) and the National Academy of Education (NAEd), with Felice J. Levine, Executive Director of the American Educational Research Association and Lorrie A. Shepard, Dean and Distinguished Professor in Research and Methodology in the School of Education at the University of Colorado-Boulder (and a Past President of the NAEd) serving as the principal investigators for the DocStudy. The National Science Foundation provided support for the study through its competitive award process.

The DocStudy was designed to parallel the National Research Council’s (NRC) 2006 Assessment of Research Doctorate Programs in the other arts and sciences fields. Like the NRC assessment, the AERA-NAEd DocStudy included program-level data provided by participating institutions as well as faculty and student surveys. Particularly during the planning stages of the DocStudy, consultation occurred with the NRC study director and related project leadership, who provided valuable information about the conceptual and operational aspects of the assessment and areas where improvements might be possible in the DocStudy. Mathematica Policy Research Inc., which collected the data for the NRC Assessment, also collected data for the DocStudy,

The education research doctorate programs offered in the participating institutions provide the substantive knowledge, methodological skills, and research training essential for the next generation of scholars studying education, teaching, and learning processes. Education research is among the largest doctorate-producing fields (approximately 2,500 each year) and the sole one dedicated to understanding science and mathematics education, learning, literacy, and achievement. Quality education research scientists are critical to producing knowledge about teaching and learning that can advance the STEM sciences. Building and strengthening knowledge about education research doctorate programs in these fields is integral to strengthening the infrastructure of U.S. science. Yet, prior to the DocStudy, there had been no comprehensive study of education research doctorate programs nor had there been an assessment of the state of education and training. 

The study provides critical data and findings that can be used to advance and improve education research doctorate programs nationally. In addition to collecting and reporting on program attributes (e.g., program and curriculum characteristics, student support and engagement in research, student and faculty demographics, scholarly impact and productivity of faculty), this study assesses elements of methodological and conceptual preparation of education research doctorates. For example, an empirically-derived taxonomy was developed for education research doctorate fields that permits identifying and distinguishing between research doctorate programs and comparing programs in specific education research fields across institutions.
